foundit66

Alaska Governor Sarah Palin is to resign this month and will not run for re-election.
 
 Gov Palin was vice presidential running-mate to Republican presidential candidate John McCain in last year's election and rallied the party's conservative base.
 
 There has been speculation that she would seek to be the Republican Party's presidential candidate in 2012.
 
 'She didn't take any questions,' in making the announcement in Alaska, Andrew Wellner, a reporter for The Frontiersman, told CNN.
 
 'She did say in her speech that she feels she can be more effective working outside of government'.
 
 Ms Palin said her decision came after much 'prayer and consideration'.
 
 She said she did not want to waste time on 'political blood sport' and cited public criticism of her actions and her family since the 2008 campaign.

 RTÉ News: Palin to resign as Alaska governor
 
 Any Argentinian stamps on her passport?
 :p

The shortest distance between two points is a straight line.
 Doesn't mean it's always the way that gets you there the quickest or the safest...
 
 The "when it's used" is the key part of your sentence that you're ignoring the SERIOUS importance to.
 
 Here is the REAL question that should be broached here..
 You have two options.
 A) Abstinence only education.
 B) Sex ed that includes ALL methods of birth control, including abstinence.
 
 So for B, "when it's used", we get FEWER teen-age pregnancies.
 Ergo, which teaching method should we use???

 
 The problem there is that it approaches abstinence as if it were just another form of birth control. That's not what it is. It's simply not having sex, rather than dealing with the CONSEQUENCES of sex. It's like saying that, if we want to deal with the problem of speeding, we should not have an approach that says "we simply shouldn't speed", but that we should also buy radar detectors, radar jammers, and anything else that will deal with the consequences of our failures. People are not automotons--believe it or not, they can choose to not have sex if they want. The stats that say abstinence doesn't work are flawed because they approach abstinence as a birth control method, in the same way they do, say, condoms. That's not the way it is AT ALL.
 
 More to the point, here is the exchange with Palin over the "abstinence-only" thing that anti-Palin people try to use against her ... note that, unlike Foundit's portrayal of the issue, the questioner did NOT include abstinence as an option in his second option he gave her:
 
 "Will you support funding for abstinence-until-marriage education instead of for explicit sex-education programs, school-based clinics, and the distribution of contraceptives in schools?"
 
 Palin: "Yes, the explicit sex-ed programs will not find my support."
 
 Note the either/or scenario of the question, to begin with. 
 
 a.) abstinence-until marriage
 
 b.) explicit-sex ed programs, school based clinics, contraceptive distribution ..... but no mention of abstinence.
 
 The question that so many liberals use as their base to attack Palin really wasn't a fair one to begin with.
 Furthermore, Palin has said she is "abstinence until marriage". That basically means she thinks kids should wait until they are married to have sex. She did NOT say "abstinence-ONLY"--as in, juxtaposed to birth control methods.
 
 Not only that, but what's the REAL kicker is .... Palin's position is apparently the VERY OPPOSITE (!) of what Foundit is portraying her as.
 
 In a widely quoted 2006 survey she answered during her gubernatorial campaign, Palin said she supported abstinence-until-marriage programs [the liberally-spun piece referenced above]. But weeks later, she proclaimed herself "pro-contraception" and said condoms ought to be discussed in schools alongside abstinence.
 
 "I'm pro-contraception, and I think kids who may not hear about it at home should hear about it in other avenues," she said during a debate in Juneau.
 
 "Palin spokeswoman Maria Comella said the governor stands by her 2006 statement, supporting sex education that covers both abstinence and contraception." (http://articles.latimes.com/2008/sep/06/nation/na-sexed6 )
 
 Wow.
 Can't get any clearer than that. Here we see, Foundit, you say Palin is abstinence-only, when straight up, she says quite the opposite. Kinda wrecks the whole strategy of dragging in her daughter for hypocrisy-charges against Palin, huh?
